title: Holby City review with spoilers: Evil Evan haunts Holby as Jac’s nightmare comes true
text:
Evil Evan manifests himself in the locker room (Picture: BBC)

Holby City viewers thought they’d seen the last of Evil Evan Crowhurst (Jack Ryder), but he was back tonight – as a ghost. Only we and Cameron (Nic Jackman), haunted by his guilt over letting Evan die, could see him but dead Evan is every bit as nasty as alive Evan.

This was bound to distract Cameron, as did the fact that he’d cremated his mum earlier that morning in the latest instalment of ‘Bernie Wolfe: The Long Goodbye.’ So he really should have taken Serena (Catherine Russell)’s advice and gone home, but nobody ever takes advice on Holby so he popped himself into his scrubs and got on with his day.

His patient o’ the week was Ged (Ben Fox), of Farmer Ged’s Fun Farm – ‘A brilliant day out with the kids’ as Donna (Jaye Jacobs) pointed out. Ged hadn’t had a brilliant day, as he’d impaled his bum on a nail and bumped his head while dressed as the Grim Reaper (for a special Halloween themed activity). Cameron didn’t like the Grim Reaper mask because it was too much like Evil Expired Evan, and nor did the adorable children who’d descended on AAU for trick or treat. But Ged was a sweetheart under the costume and Cameron was able to talk to him about Bernie.

When Ged deteriorated, Serena discovered that the nail he’d fallen on had been much larger than Cameron had assumed and had caused a serious injury that needed surgery. Ged told Cameron he had a bad feeling about the operation and made Cameron promise to tell Ged’s family that he loved them if he shouldn’t survive.

He did survive the op, but went into septic shock soon afterwards and died. ‘You’re killing him like you did me,’ said Ghastly Ghostly Evan. Poor Cameron was unable to talk to Ged’s family as he’d promised and got Serena to do it, and then went to scatter Bernie’s ashes in the Linden Cullen Memorial Shrubbery, under the Wyvern Wing sign. It’s what she would have wanted.

Sacha’s concerned about Jac (Picture: BBC)

Jac (Rosie Marcel)’s mental health is starting to be a worry now. Another glimpse of Joseph (Luke Roberts) in the ‘Previously’ section (sigh) suggests that losing him again has taken its toll on her, but the immediate concern is the fear that she’s about to lose daughter Emma. Another visit from Stacey (Emily Bowker), Jonny Maconie’s ‘human shield’ as Jac referred to her, confirmed Jac’s fears. The Maconies are moving to Edinburgh and apparently Jonny wants custody of Emma. This revelation came right at the end of an episode in which Jac had assumed it was Stacey who was trying to take her little girl away. Jac warned her that ‘If you try any such thing I will come for you and that ineffectual excuse of a man you married and I will eviscerate you.’

Jac’s words are still hard but we saw at various times that she’s not coping – she had a panic attack and was really horrible to Fletch (Alex Walkinshaw) when he tried to help. She also pushed Sacha (Bob Barrett) away when he noticed that she seemed subdued.

Can’t he be left alone to do a Wordsearch in peace like all the other patients? (Picture: BBC)

Her mood wasn’t helped by Kian (Ramin Karimloo). As predicted, Bea (Rosalind Halstead) was back after the heart valve repair that Kian had done failed. Jac was furious with him, particularly when she spotted Kian and Bea holding hands, because remember she went to university with Kian so she also remembers Bea. She tried to get Kian to resign as Clinical Lead, but he denied everything, Fletch said he’d seen no proof and Nicky (Belinda Owusu) had been warned by Kian to keep quiet. Jac isn’t used to being undermined in this way.

Meanwhile, Helen (Verity Marshall) was at the hospital for an ante natal class. Dominic (David Ames) assumed (quite reasonably, I think, from what Helen said) that he and Lofty (Lee Mead) were both invited, so he dutifully turned up. After he fell asleep during the relaxation exercises and Helen had to send both him and Lofty out of the room because they were being annoying, it became clear that Helen wasn’t happy with Dominic’s involvement. ‘I’m not sure how much a party of this Lofty even wants to be,’ she said. ‘Neither do I,’ said Lofty. And neither do I, if it causes this much Dofty conflict before the baby is even born.

Advertisement

In other news, the hospital is 150 years old next week. There’s only that arched bit on AAU that looks remotely that old, as the rest of it was clearly built in the 1960s, but perhaps Fletch will allude to that in the speech he wanted Ric Griffin (Hugh Quarshie)’s help to write. As Holby’s longest-serving surgeon, the health minister would definitely want to meet Ric at the ceremony, Fletch told him. ‘I must remember to wear my formal pyjamas,’ Ric sighed as he tried his best to recover from brain surgery without being harassed by colleagues.

Sue Haasler is the author of five novels and the official BBC Holby City book, which you can read about here.

description: The Halloween season brought with it plenty of fears for Holby's finest, as Jac's worries got on top of her, while Cameron saw an old face.
